title: How to Change the Battery on a Sleeptracker

steps.headline: Identify that the battery really needs changed.
steps.description: Symptoms include a dim screen, lackluster backlight, poor sound, and the watch randomly resetting itself.

steps.headline: Order a battery online or go out and buy one from a brick and mortar store if you can't wait.
steps.description: Note it will be many times more expensive at a store. You will need a CR2032 battery. You can find a five pack on eBay for $1. Usually cheap ones have a lot of life.

steps.headline: Collect the tools that you will need (see the "Things You'll Need" section below for a list of tools.)
Once you have your tools you can begin.
steps.description: Find a good clean surface to work on. Wash your hands as best you can. You don't want to get any dirt and especially any oil into your watch, as it can rust it slowly over time. Clean your pointy object.

steps.headline: Use the screwdriver to take the four screws off the back of the watch.
steps.description: Small watch threads are easy to strip, so be as careful as possible while still using the necessary force.

steps.headline: Once you have all of the screws loosened, remove the case back.
steps.description: Set aside the screws and be sure not to lose them. Be careful not to get grease or dirt on the inside of the caseback.

steps.headline: Put on your gloves if you have them.
steps.description: If you do not, make sure that your hands are clean. When you have the case back off, do not rotate the watch so it is vertical or flipped over. You will usually lose the small gold springs on the inside of the watch which are key for many of its functions. Once they are lost they are very hard to reattach.

steps.headline: Try not to detach the small layer of plastic (it's over the inside of the watch, and it has several holes in it), as it will be hard to get back on.
steps.description:
It is attached fairly well though, so don't worry very much. There is an indentation, usually with black plastic on the inside of it around the battery. The plastic should not be covering it. Slide your small flat screwdriver or pointy object into it and pry the battery out. Don't worry about damaging the battery, but try not to do it quickly and damage the electronics below the battery. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/e\/e5\/Change-the-Battery-on-a-Sleeptracker-Step-8Bullet1.jpg\/v4-460px-Change-the-Battery-on-a-Sleeptracker-Step-8Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/e\/e5\/Change-the-Battery-on-a-Sleeptracker-Step-8Bullet1.jpg\/v4-760px-Change-the-Battery-on-a-Sleeptracker-Step-8Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"}

steps.headline: Slide the battery under and out of the plastic layer and discard it once it is dislodged.
Take your new battery out of its casing.
steps.description: Try not to dirty it. If you have a voltmeter, check its voltage. New ones should be between 3 and 3.3 volts. Otherwise, proceed. Slide the battery under the plastic and into its slot. Be sure to insert it with the side stating its battery type and voltage up, look how the old one was.

steps.headline: Put the watch above your head to see if it is working.
steps.description: Do not put it vertical or flip it over. If it isn't, make sure the battery is properly snapped into place.

steps.headline: Grease the gasket if you have silicon grease.
steps.description: Greasing the gasket will help ensure your watch remains waterproof and will keep the gasket in good shape, so it won't need to be replaced.

steps.headline: Gently pull the gasket (it is black and all around the exterior of the inside) out, and put a thin layer all over it.
steps.description: Be sure not to tear it. Do not use motor grease, axle grease or anything else that isn't designed for gaskets.

steps.headline: Gently place the gasket back into place.
steps.description: Be sure it is in the right way.

steps.headline: Put your case back back over the watch.
steps.description: Be sure it is aligned properly, as it is easy to mess up. Start screwing the screws in, and don't tighten them down if the case looks off. Try to put them down firmly, but not extremely hard. If you tighten them as hard as you can, you will probably strip them.

text:
Identify that the battery really needs changed. Symptoms include a dim screen, lackluster backlight, poor sound, and the watch randomly resetting itself. Order a battery online or go out and buy one from a brick and mortar store if you can't wait. Note it will be many times more expensive at a store. You will need a CR2032 battery. You can find a five pack on eBay for $1. Usually cheap ones have a lot of life. Collect the tools that you will need (see the "Things You'll Need" section below for a list of tools.) Once you have your tools you can begin. Find a good clean surface to work on. Wash your hands as best you can. You don't want to get any dirt and especially any oil into your watch, as it can rust it slowly over time. Clean your pointy object. Use the screwdriver to take the four screws off the back of the watch. Small watch threads are easy to strip, so be as careful as possible while still using the necessary force. Once you have all of the screws loosened, remove the case back. Set aside the screws and be sure not to lose them. Be careful not to get grease or dirt on the inside of the caseback. Put on your gloves if you have them. If you do not, make sure that your hands are clean. When you have the case back off, do not rotate the watch so it is vertical or flipped over. You will usually lose the small gold springs on the inside of the watch which are key for many of its functions. Once they are lost they are very hard to reattach. Try not to detach the small layer of plastic (it's over the inside of the watch, and it has several holes in it), as it will be hard to get back on. It is attached fairly well though, so don't worry very much. There is an indentation, usually with black plastic on the inside of it around the battery. The plastic should not be covering it. Slide your small flat screwdriver or pointy object into it and pry the battery out. Don't worry about damaging the battery, but try not to do it quickly and damage the electronics below the battery. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/e\/e5\/Change-the-Battery-on-a-Sleeptracker-Step-8Bullet1.jpg\/v4-460px-Change-the-Battery-on-a-Sleeptracker-Step-8Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/e\/e5\/Change-the-Battery-on-a-Sleeptracker-Step-8Bullet1.jpg\/v4-760px-Change-the-Battery-on-a-Sleeptracker-Step-8Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Slide the battery under and out of the plastic layer and discard it once it is dislodged. Take your new battery out of its casing. Try not to dirty it. If you have a voltmeter, check its voltage. New ones should be between 3 and 3.3 volts. Otherwise, proceed. Slide the battery under the plastic and into its slot. Be sure to insert it with the side stating its battery type and voltage up, look how the old one was. Put the watch above your head to see if it is working. Do not put it vertical or flip it over. If it isn't, make sure the battery is properly snapped into place. Grease the gasket if you have silicon grease. Greasing the gasket will help ensure your watch remains waterproof and will keep the gasket in good shape, so it won't need to be replaced. Gently pull the gasket (it is black and all around the exterior of the inside) out, and put a thin layer all over it. Be sure not to tear it. Do not use motor grease, axle grease or anything else that isn't designed for gaskets. Gently place the gasket back into place. Be sure it is in the right way. Put your case back back over the watch. Be sure it is aligned properly, as it is easy to mess up. Start screwing the screws in, and don't tighten them down if the case looks off. Try to put them down firmly, but not extremely hard. If you tighten them as hard as you can, you will probably strip them.
